Square and round brackets denote editorial insertions or emendations. 1 Sonderliche his man astoned In his owene mende, Wanne he not? neuer wannes he com√æe, Ne wider he schel wende; And more, √ûet al his lyf his here imengde Wi√æe sorwe and eke wi√æe sore. 2 And wanne he dei√æe, ne mey me wite Woder he come√æ to wisse; Bote as a stock √æer li√æe √æet body, Wi√æe-√æoute alle manere blisse. Bi leddre. Howe mey √æat be? wo dar √æer-oppe stei?e, For dou?te of fotes bleddre? 7 Man, √æy laddre nys nau?t of wode √ûat may to heuene leste; Ac on √æer his, √æat iakob isei?e √ûer he sleppe inne hys reste. For gode, Hou my?te fayrer signe be √ûane of √æe water and blode? 14 Man, √æorwe √æat blod √æi soule his bou?t Fram √æe fendes powere; And √æorwe √æat water iwessche √æart Of √æyne sennes here. Wanne we take√æ √æe sacremens, √ûar we se√æ hit √æanne. 25 √ûa? we ne mowe hyt nau?t ise, Ne for√æe ine bodie iurede, We se√æe hit wel ine oure fey, And frede√æ hit at nede Wel e?a√æe: God √æorwe miracles ke√æe√æ hit A lyue and eke a de√æe. 26 And bote he √æorwe hys sacremens Ous √æos bi-redde, Ne scholde we of his grace wite Wanne we hit toke and hedde To wisse; √ûer-fore, he √æat bi-lefe√æ hit nau?t Ri?t wyt ne√æ of blisse. 27 Al hit be√æ cherche sacremens √ûet tokene√æ holi √æynges, As hali water, and haly bred, Li?t, and belryngynges To leste; And of alle o√æer sacremens √ûes seuene be√æ √æe greste. (1) [D]E baptismo. 28 Cristendom his √æat sacrement √ûat men her ferst fonge√æ; Hit opene√æ to ous √æe heuene blisse, √ûat many man after longe√æ Wel sore; For who √æat entre√æ √æer He his sauff euere more. 29 Nou ferst ich wille telle ?ou Wet may be √æe materie Wer-inne cristning may be mad, √ûat bringe√æ ous so merie To honoure: Hi?t mo?t be do ine kende water, And non o√æer licour[e]. 30 √ûer-fore ine wine me ne may, Inne si√æere, ne inne pereye, Ne ine √æing √æat neuere water nes √ûor? cristning man reneye; Ne inne ale, For, √æie hi?t were water ferst, Of water ne√æ hit tale. 31 Ne mede, ne for√æe no o√æer licour √ûat chaunge√æ wateres kende, Ne longe√æ nau?t to cristendom, √ûa?t some foles hit wende For wete; For suich is kendeliche hot, √ûa?t √æer no feer hit ne hete. 32 Ac water is kendeliche cheld, √ûa? hit be warmd of fere; √ûer-fore me mey cristni √æer-inne, In whaut time fal√æe a ?ere Of yse; So mey me nau?t in ewe ardaunt, √ûat ne√æ no wateris wyse. 33 Al-so me may inne sealte se Cristny wel mitte beste, And eke inne o√æere sealte watere, Bote me in to moche kes(ch)te Of sealte; For ?ef √æat water his kende lest, √ûat cristning stant te tealte. 34 Ac ?yf √æer were ymengd licour O√æer wid kende wetere, Ich wo?t wel, √ærinne to cristnye Hit nere nefur √æe betere, Ac wonde; For bote √æat water his kende haue, √ûat cristnynge may nau?t stonde. 35 In water ich wel √æe cristny her, As gode him self hyt di?te; For mide to wessche nis no√æynge √ûat man come√æ to so li?te; In londe Nis non √æat habben hit ne may: √ûat habbe hit wile, founde. 36 √ûis be√æe √æe wordes of cristnyng Bi √æyse englissche costes:‚Äî ‚ÄúIch cristni √æe ine √æe uader name, And sone, and holy gostes;‚Äù And more, ‚ÄúAmen!‚Äù Wane hit his ised √æer-toe, Conferme√æ √æet to-fore. 37 √ûe wordes scholle be ised Wi√æe-oute wane and eche; And onderstand, hi mo?e bi sed In alle manere speche Ine lede, √ûat euerich man hi sigge mo?e, And cristny for nede. 38 Ac ?if man scholde icristnid be √ûat ne√æ none dea√æes signe, √ûe pope for te cristny hyne So nere nau?t te digne √ûe leste; √ûer-fore hi be√æ in cherche brou?t To cristny of √æe preste. 39 Ac he √æat ?if so large water √ûe fend fram ous te reaue, In nede for to cristny men ?ef alle men ileaue At felle; Olepi mot hym ine √æe water, And eke √æe wordes telle. 40 And wanne hi cristne√æ ine √æe foun?t, √ûe prestes so √æries depe√æ, In √æe honur of √æe trinite, Ac gode ?eme kepe√æ √ûe ned On time a clo√æe √æat water ikest, Ac ope √æe heuede te bede. 41 Ac water ikest an o√æer leme Cristne√æ √æe man alyue, Ac hit his sikerest in √æe heeued, √ûer be√æ √æe wittes fyue. Wel, bro√æer, Ne non ne may icristned be Ar he his boren of moder. 42 ?et gret peryl hy vndergo√æe √ûat cristne√æ twyes enne, O√æer to ?eue asent √æer-to, O√æer for loue of kenne For-hede√æ Wanne child ari?t cristnyng he√æ, And √æat o√æer nau?t for-bede√æ. 43 Bote hi √æis conne, hit his peril To √æise medewyues; For ofte children scheawi√æ quike, Ibore to schorte lyues, And deye√æ: Bote hi ari?t icristned be, Fram heuene euere hi weye√æ. 44 Ac ?if √æat child icristned his, Ac me fot at me hit wene√æ, √ûise habbe√æ forme √æer-of A latin √æat ham genie√æ To depe; And ich schel seggen hit an englisch, Nou √æer-of neme ?e kepe. 45 √ûe prest take√æ √æat ilke child In his honden by-thuixte, And sei√æ: ‚Äúich ne cristni √æei nau?t, ?ef √æou ert icristned;‚Äù Eft sone:‚Äî ‚ÄúAc ?yf √æou nart, ich cristni √æe;‚Äù And de√æ √æat his to donne. 46 Ac ?et √æer be√æ cristnynges mo, Ac no man ne may di?tti; For hi be√æ godes grace self, Men of gode wil to ri?ti And wynne, Wanne hi wolde icristned be, And mo?e mid none ginne. 47 √ûat on his cleped cristning of blode, Wanne suche blede√æ for criste; √ûat o√æer of √æe holy gost, √ûat mo?e mid none liste Be icristned, And deye√æ so: wanne hi be√æ deede, Ine heuene hi be√æ igistned. 48 √ûe children atte cherche dore So be√æ yprimisined; And √æat hi bee√æe eke atte fount Mid oylle and creyme alyned Al faylle√æ; Hi?t wor√æe√æ cristnyng, and √æat child √ûer-to hit auaille√æ. o√æer eft for-sake. 246 √ûat hys, bote hy wedded be To o√æren er hy hy?t by-knewe; For √æa? hy by-knowe hyt, Ne hys nau?t y-helde trewe By lawe; For ?ef hy were, hyt scholde be √ûese spousebrechene sawe. 247 Of ham √æat scholde ywedded be Her √æe age √æou my?t lerne: √ûet knaue child for-tene ?er Schel habbe, ane tuel √æe √æerne. hy ne libbe; Wat de√æ hy?t?
